Instrument.name: Phoenix Lander Meteorology Suite LIDAR
Instrument.description: The Phoenix Lander Meteorology Suite (MET) LIDAR recorded the height profile of laser backscatter from the dust and cloud layers that drifted past the landing site with a view that is continuous in time. The attenuation of the lidar signal was used to derive the optical extinction coefficient and this is related to atmospheric properties. The combination of the lidar and passive remote sensing with in situ sampling provided a view of the interacting processes that determine the local weather at the surface and also the role of the atmosphere in the water cycle on Mars. A basic atmospheric lidar (light detection and ranging) emits pulses of laser light into the atmosphere then detects and records the backscattered light as a function of time. The time resolved signal is converted to distance using the speed of light and a factor of two to account for the round-trip path length.
